Criteria: Care about the patient’s feelings
Good example: How are you feeling right now? Is there anything in particular that’s bothering you?
Bad example: How you feel isn’t important—just do it my way first.

Criteria: Care about the family’s feelings
Good example: I know this is hard for the family too. You can tell me together what you’re worried about.
Bad example: Family members shouldn’t get involved—let the patient decide alone.

Criteria: Explain the condition with empathy
Good example: I know this diagnosis feels sudden. I’ll explain it step by step so you can understand.
Bad example: That’s just how it is. Do you get it or not?

Criteria: Offer choices rather than giving orders
Good example: There are a few options here. Let’s look at them together and see what fits you best.
Bad example: Don’t choose—just do what I say.

Criteria: Encourage the patient to share
Good example: Would you be willing to share what’s on your mind?
Bad example: If you don’t tell me, I can’t help—please say it quickly.

Criteria: Acknowledge the patient’s concerns
Good example: I can hear that you’re worried. I’m here with you, and we’ll go through each step together.
Bad example: What are you worried about? Don’t overthink it.

Criteria: Acknowledge the family’s concerns
Good example: I understand you’re worried about the patient’s condition. I’ll explain it more clearly so you can feel reassured.
Bad example: If the family is too anxious, it only creates more trouble.

Criteria: Identify the patient’s unspoken concerns
Good example: I’d like to check—are there any other concerns you haven’t said out loud yet?
Bad example: If you have something to say, say it quickly so I can get on with my work.

Criteria: Identify the family’s unspoken concerns
Good example: I’d like to check—do you have any other concerns you haven’t mentioned yet?
Bad example: Stop holding back—I don’t have time to guess.

Criteria: Validate the patient’s emotional reaction
Good example: It’s normal to feel this way. I’m here to support you.
Bad example: Tone down the emotions, or we can’t have this conversation.

Criteria: Explain the condition in plain language
Good example: Let me put it more simply: this situation isn’t immediately dangerous.
Bad example: If you don’t understand, it’s because your basics are lacking.

Criteria: Use a simple analogy to explain the condition
Good example: You can think of this condition like a warning light—your body is telling you it needs rest.
Bad example: You should be able to understand this analogy on your own, right?

Criteria: Reference clinical guidelines when explaining recommendations
Good example: Based on current treatment guidelines, this option is the safest and most effective.
Bad example: Just follow the guidelines—no need to ask.

Criteria: Check the patient’s understanding of the condition
Good example: I’d like to confirm: is your understanding of what I said the same as mine?
Bad example: If you misunderstood, that’s your problem.

Criteria: Check the family’s understanding of the condition
Good example: Let me quickly confirm again—are you all clear about the current situation?
Bad example: How do you still not understand?

Criteria: Ask the patient to explain their understanding of the condition
Good example: What do you think is going on with your condition right now? Could you share your view?
Bad example: I already told you—if you get it wrong again, that’s on you.

Criteria: Provide sufficient treatment options
Good example: You have several treatment options. I can help you compare the differences.
Bad example: Either way it’s this option—don’t consider anything else.

Criteria: Notice and align the patient’s understanding
Good example: Your description helps me understand how you see the condition. We can verify it together.
Bad example: You have too many misunderstandings—I don’t have time to correct them.

Criteria: Explain the treatment plan in detail
Good example: This treatment has three steps. I’ll explain them one by one so it’s clear.
Bad example: The treatment is simple—you don’t need the details.

Criteria: Confirm gaps in understanding between clinician and patient
Good example: Let’s align our understanding first so there won’t be misunderstandings later.
Bad example: If you don’t understand, then don’t make decisions.

Criteria: Offer a plan without making guarantees
Good example: I can suggest possible treatment directions, but the outcome may still need adjustment based on how your body responds.
Bad example: This plan will definitely be 100% effective.

Criteria: Explain treatment risks
Good example: I need to remind you: although this treatment can help, it may also have some expected side effects.
Bad example: There’s basically no risk—don’t think too much.

Criteria: Explain treatment risks
Good example: You may feel some discomfort during the course. I’ll tell you in advance how to handle it.
Bad example: If there’s risk, you can just bear it yourself.

Criteria: Provide guideline-based advice and encourage verification
Good example: If you have any concerns, you can also confirm with specialist clinicians that the information source is correct.
Bad example: Stop looking things up—you can only trust me.

Criteria: Confirm allergy history
Good example: Do you have any allergies to medications or foods?
Bad example: Allergies aren’t important.

Criteria: Confirm past medical history
Good example: I need to know your past medical history first so we can plan the safest treatment approach.
Bad example: Your medical history is too much trouble—doesn’t matter if you don’t mention it.

Criteria: Confirm anticoagulant use
Good example: I’d like to confirm whether you’re taking anticoagulants regularly, to avoid bleeding risks during treatment.
Bad example: Whether you’re taking anticoagulants isn’t important—we’ll talk about it later.

Criteria: Check for drug interactions / other medications
Good example: Are you currently taking any other medications, so we can avoid interactions?
Bad example: Drug interactions aren’t my problem.

Criteria: Give safety advice and warning signs
Good example: If you develop any unusual symptoms, please come back immediately or contact the ER.
Bad example: If something goes wrong, you deal with it yourself.

Criteria: Confirm and correct any mismatch in understanding
Good example: I’d like to confirm again that we’re on the same page, to avoid misunderstandings.
Bad example: If you misunderstood, that’s your responsibility.
